page.title: 02Ecology of the Downs 1
page.content: The landscape consists mainly of downland used as rough grazing and of scrub (inc. gorse, hawthorne, bramble & elder); the three farms in the area also cultivate about one third of the land with crops such as oats and barley. All of the downland is public property and even the farms are owned by Eastbourne Corporation. This has the result that where sheep no longer graze and keep down the level of plant-life this land has become overgrown with scrub. Sheep are by far the best animals for grazing the downland as they prevent scrub growing to any height without killing off the grass by eating too close to the ground; also, as they are not heavy, they do not break the surface of the turf.
